snippet: The performance space Littlefield hosts a crafts fair and performances by young musicians, while the Invisible Dog Art Center presents readings by Jennifer Egan and Luc Sante.
lead_paragraph: Around the turn of this century, the Miser knew a saxophonist in Brooklyn who would walk to rehearsals in Park Slope from his home in Carroll Gardens. He would head warily down Union Street, past dead, silent factories and the rusting remains of another era. On the Union Street Bridge he'd pause to hear, carried on the chemically compromised air wafting up from the Gowanus Canal underfoot, the high, lonesome singing of the stray dogs that roamed the neighborhood. Rather improbably, the Gowanus section of Brooklyn has, over the last several years, come into its own as a scrappy cultural district. Then again, if living in New York has taught the Miser anything, it's this: Never underestimate the transformative powers of overeducated bohemians, given enough underused industrial space.

headline.main: Free Events at Littlefield, and a PEN Reading in Carroll Gardens
